article:
My father was a self-taught mandolin player. He was one of the best players in our town. He could not _ music, but if he heard a tune a few times, he could play it. When he was young, he was a _ of a small country music band. They played at local dances and the radio station.
At home Dad often got out his mandolin and played for the family. We three children sang along. _ played the mandolin like my father. He could _ your heart with the music that came out of that old mandolin. He seemed to shine when he was playing. You could see his _ in his ability to play so well for his family.
But Dad had to find another _ in a factory later because the money he made at the band wasn't enough to _ the family. Unluckily he had an _ one day and lost one finger. He couldn't play as _ as before. From then on, every time we asked him to play, he would make up reasons to _ down our request. However, we missed his performance so much. _ , he agreed and said "Okay, but remember, I can't hold down on the strings the way I _ to". When he played the old mandolin, it carried us back to a _ , happy time in our lives.
Dad was that kind of man. _ was what he was doing all his life. If he could give _ to others, he would, especially his family. He was always there, sacrificing his time to see that his family had enough in their life.
